pullRequest.body:
This PR introduces a Prop-valued mixin class for root pairings, specifying that a bilinear form on weight space is symmetric, reflection-invariant, and gives roots a strictly positive norm.  Given a root-positive norm, one obtains sign-compatibilities between the form and the canonical pairing between roots and coroots.

Root-positive forms show up naturally in Kac-Moody Lie algebras (without the name), and the canonical polarization on a finite root pairing induces a root-positive form.

---


[![Open in Gitpod](https://gitpod.io/button/open-in-gitpod.svg)](https://gitpod.io/from-referrer/)

### PR summary [4054dec36e](https://github.com/leanprover-community/mathlib4/pull/15155/commits/4054dec36e8cdeae1a5476b3fbee2bc7bd94ecba)

#### Import changes for modified files

No significant changes to the import graph


<details><summary>Import changes for all files</summary>

|Files|Import difference|
|-|-|
| `Mathlib.LinearAlgebra.RootSystem.RootPositive`|1195|

</details>

---

<details><summary>

#### Declarations diff

</summary>

`+ IsRootPositive`
`+ apply_root_root_zero_iff`
`+ coxeterWeight_non_neg`
`+ coxeterWeight_zero_iff_isOrthogonal`
`+ pairing_zero_iff`
`+ two_mul_apply_root_root`
`+ zero_lt_apply_root_root_iff`
`+ zero_lt_pairing_iff`
<details>
  <summary>You can run this locally as follows</summary>


```bash
## summary with just the declaration names:
./scripts/declarations_diff.sh <optional_commit>

## more verbose report:
./scripts/declarations_diff.sh long <optional_commit>
```
</details>
The doc-module for `script/declarations_diff.sh` contains some details about this script.

</details>

That is an excellent question, and I do not have a good answer.  The current notion of `root-positive` appears to be both useful and general.  However, in all of the cases that I encounter, standard constructions give "root-positive" forms on both weight and coweight spaces.  In particular, both the "standard polarization" on a finite root datum, and Kac's construction of an invariant bilinear form for Kac-Moody Lie algebras satisfy this property.  So, perhaps there is something more fundamental that I am missing.  The only factor that I can see tying these two constructions together is the existence of distinguished subspaces of `M` and `N` that contain all of the roots (resp. coroots), on which the root-positive forms are nondegenerate.

:v: ScottCarnahan can now approve this pull request. To approve and merge a pull request, simply reply with `bors r+`. More detailed instructions are available [here](https://bors.tech/documentation/getting-started/#reviewing-pull-requests).

Thank you for the review!
bors r+

Pull request successfully merged into master.

Build succeeded:
  * [Build](https://github.com/leanprover-community/mathlib4/actions/runs/10154887239/job/28080743601)
  * [Lint style](https://github.com/leanprover-community/mathlib4/actions/runs/10154887239/job/28080743234)

In the finite case my naive guess would be that the compatibility condition between bilinear forms on $M$ and $N$ would be that if we have $v$, $w$ in $N$ then:
$$\sum_{i,j}\langle v, \alpha_i\rangle \langle w, \alpha_j\rangle B_M(\alpha_i, \alpha_j) = B_M(\sum_i \langle v, \alpha_i\rangle \alpha_i, \sum_j \langle w, \alpha_j\rangle \alpha_j) = B_N(v, w),$$
where $\alpha_i$ is the ith root and $\langle v, x\rangle$ is the perfect pairing (for $x$ in $M$).

In any case, the current proposal makes sense and is useful.

bors d+
Thanks, just a few nitpicks.

I've added a final round of trivial code suggestions but I also have a mathematical question.

Is `IsRootPositive` definitely the right definition even though it completely ignores the coroots? For example if `B` is non-singular, we get a bilinear form on `N` but it's not immediately clear to me that this will be a "root positive" form wrt the coroots.

In the finite case my naive guess would be that the compatibility condition between bilinear forms on $M$ and $N$ would be that if we have $v$, $w$ in $N$ then:
$$\sum_{i,j}\langle v, \alpha_i\rangle \langle w, \alpha_j\rangle B_M(\alpha_i, \alpha_j) = B_M(\sum_i \langle v, \alpha_i\rangle \alpha_i, \sum_j \langle w, \alpha_j\rangle \alpha_j) = B_N(v, w),$$
where $\alpha_i$ is the ith root and $\langle v, x\rangle$ is the perfect pairing (for $x$ in $M$).

In any case, the current proposal makes sense and is useful.

bors d+

How about making the names of these fields closer to their types:
```suggestion
  zero_lt_apply_root :  i, 0 < B (P.root i) (P.root i)
  symm :  x y, B x y = B y x
  apply_reflection_eq :  i x y, B (P.reflection i x) (P.reflection i y) = B x y
```

Looks like we don't need this.
```suggestion
```
I'm not absolutely convinced we need these (though I'm happy to be persuaded if you disagree).

Again I think I'd find this name more guessable as something like:
```suggestion
lemma two_mul_apply_root_root :
```

I think this would make a great `simp` lemma if we flip the LHS and RHS. How about we also tweak the name and golf slightly as:
```suggestion
@[simp]
lemma zero_lt_apply_root_root_iff : 0 < B (P.root i) (P.root j)  0 < P.pairing i j := by
  refine fun h  (mul_pos_iff_of_pos_right (root_positive P B j)).mp ?_,
    fun h  (mul_pos_iff_of_pos_left zero_lt_two).mp ?_
   rw [ two_mul_inner_product]
    exact mul_pos zero_lt_two h
   rw [two_mul_inner_product]
    exact mul_pos h (root_positive P B j)
```

I think it's worth upgrading this to an iff:
```suggestion
lemma zero_lt_pairing_iff : 0 < P.pairing i j  0 < P.pairing j i := by
```

Again, I think this would be a great `simp` lemma if we flip the LHS and RHS:
```suggestion
lemma apply_root_root_zero_iff : B (P.root i) (P.root j) = 0  P.pairing i j = 0 := by
```

I slightly prefer
```suggestion
  zero_lt_apply_root :  i, 0 < B (P.root i) (P.root i)
  symm :  x y, B x y = B y x
  apply_reflection_eq :  i x y, B (P.reflection i x) (P.reflection i y) = B x y
```
(but feel free to ignore)

```suggestion
lemma coxeterWeight_non_neg : 0  P.coxeterWeight i j := by
```

```suggestion
  refine fun hB  ?_, fun hP  ?_
   have h2 : 2 * B (P.root i) (P.root j) = 0 := mul_eq_zero_of_right 2 hB
    rw [two_mul_apply_root_root] at h2
    exact eq_zero_of_ne_zero_of_mul_right_eq_zero (IsRootPositive.zero_lt_apply_root j).ne' h2
   have h2 : 2 * B (P.root i) (P.root j) = 0 := by rw [two_mul_apply_root_root, hP, zero_mul]
    exact (mul_eq_zero.mp h2).resolve_left two_ne_zero
```

I think this should be upgraded to an `iff` as follows:
```suggestion
@[simp]
lemma coxeterWeight_zero_iff_isOrthogonal : P.coxeterWeight i j = 0  P.IsOrthogonal i j := by
```

```suggestion
  rcases h with h | h
```

```suggestion
/-- A Prop-valued class for a bilinear form to be compatible with a root pairing. -/
```

The linter has made me realise this cannot be a simp lemma because `B` is underdetermined (does not appear in the statement).
```suggestion
```

pullRequest.title: [Merged by Bors] - feat (LinearAlgebra/RootSystem/RootPositive) : Root-positive bilinear forms
